'''Cecil James Nesbitt''', Ph.D., F.S.A., M.A.A.A. (1912 – 2001) was a mathematician who was a Ph.D. student of [[Richard Brauer]] and wrote many influential papers in the early history of [[modular representation theory]].  He taught [[actuarial science|actuarial mathematics]] at the [[University of Michigan]] from 1938 to 1980.  Nesbitt was born in [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]. He received his mathematical education at the [[University of Toronto]] and the [[Institute for Advanced Study]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey|Princeton]].  He served the [[Society of Actuaries]] from 1985 to 1987 as Vice-President for Research and Studies. He developed the [[Schuette-Nesbitt formula]] with [[Donald R. Schuette]]

==See also==
* [[Schuette–Nesbitt formula]]

* Newton L. Bowers, Hans U. Gerber, James C. Hickman, Donald A. Jones, Cecil J. Nesbitt: Actuarial Mathematics. (2nd ed.), 1997, The Society of Actuaries ISBN 0-938959-46-8.
* [[Charles W. Curtis]]: Pioneers of Representation Theory. 1999, [[American Mathematical Society]] ISBN 978-0-8218-2677-5
